title.narrative: F.a: Supporting National Reconciliation in Iraq

description.narrative: Less than a year after the territorial defeat of the so-called Islamic State (IS), and after years if not decades of conflict and polarisation and populist politics alongside sectarian lines, thousands of Iraqis have been pushed to choose between violence, migration and other harsh options. Low-level violence continues, corruption is pervasive, job opportunities scarce and Iraqs youth continues to look for a future elsewhere, including in Europe. Scars within the Iraqi society remain deep and the risk of a return to large-scale violence remains, even widens, while the local, national and international perception of state-wide collapse is a prevailing thought.#The urgency for the need of good governance, anti-corruption measures and security is emphasized by continued violent protests in neglected areas in Southern Iraq and a resurgence of attacks orchestrated by the remnants of the IS in several North-Western areas of the country and Baghdad. The political system alone is incapable of rebuilding trust with ci tizens as it is regarded corrupt and distanced itself from the peoples needs this is reflected in the dismal vote participation in the first post-IS elections in May 2018.#There is a significant lack of progress on the process of reconciliation at societa l and national levels. The political will required for taking comprehensive action and committing to national-level strategy or strategies, with resources and critical support for implementing them, is inadequate and subject to some of the constraints desc ribed above. Additionally, years of armed conflict accompanied by propaganda and negative myths have led to a lack of trust between the main segments of society.#In this context, CMI seeks to strengthen dialogue contributing to societal cohesion and reconc iliation in Iraq through the promotion of positive narratives for reconciliation and trust building between main segments of the Iraqi society, strengthening links between local level and relevant government institutions for national societal reconciliatio n, and through the facilitation of informal dialogue among regional representatives and influential actors on shared concerns.
